title: why does velkoz ult slow?
body: the entire reason it can deal 2k aoe true damage, is that it has a slow turn speed and you should be able to dodge it. so why when you are not playing a champion who is overloaded with mobility like {{champion:64}} , is it impossible to escape and it oneshots you when you touch it?

replies.body:
Yeah, lets go nerf one of the champion that has caused of the least balances issues ever.

Good idea.
If you remove the slow his ult is basically useless, since it'd be simple to just walk out of it like its nothing.

well, to be fair. thats the entire idea. its why it deals so much damage.

think about it. a juggernaut like darius is fine dealing a shitton of damage because his damage is avoidable. its kindof a balancing act between counterplay and payoff when you hit a fully channeled ult. vk ult damage is absurd because it should be equally easy to counterplay by walking out of it.

so it deals a fuckton of damage because it has a slow turn speed and is easy to counter. which means you need teamplay to set him up to hit a good ult. but when you hit one, it annihilates entire teams.

lets say a {{champion:113}} stuns the entire enemy team, allowing the {{champion:161}} to follow up with a full channel of the ult on multiple opponents, then the (more like ~ 1k true damage with 3 passve procs) is well deserved.

but its true that since it has a slow attached, it automatically removes its own counterplay for champions who arent exceptionally mobile.

due to geometry, especially at long distance it becomes easier to hit  and harder to dodge out of.

For him to use the ult safely he has to be far back which means people would just run out of the remaining ult range if it did not slow. In addition, if people get too close not only will he take damage because he is channeling, but he will also be unable to deal damage with his ult because the turn speed is not nearly fast enough for close range combat.

I'd also note that his ult doesn't deal true damage until 3 passive stacks which requires about 80% of the ult duration to achieve and is highly telegraphed if stacked by abilities.

the ability deals stupid damage because it should be easy to dodge. the massive damage is supposed to be balanced because it is easy to doge. like {{champion:82}} deals stupid damage when he is close, but it is difficult for him to get close. but since {{champion:161}} ult slows, it removes its own counterplay for anyone who is not mobile like lee sin. it touches you and you can not get out of it anymore.

If it deals 2k true damage you were already half-dead anyways, since he had to trigger Research with three damage waves plus passive and then you would have to eat entire duration of that while he'd have to be extremly fed and full AP squishy.
I would assume because the ult itself moves side to side slow and it would be too hard to maintain the Ray on a moving champ otherwise.

I think it's a more general issue where a lot of abilities are given some slow just so that they're not just pure damage, and in cases like Vel and Jhin's ults it kind of messes up their counterplay. I also agree that gratuitious CC like this tends to impact low-mobility champions severely more than champions with gapclosers, so it might be better to just wipe off a lot of slows on abilities where they're not all that essential.

this is actually what i hate about this idea to attach slows to champion abilities to counter mobility.

it doesnt fucking work. the champions who are hypermobile are less affected by slows than champions who arent very mobile in the first place. youre not going to stop a {{champion:92}} from dashing out of a {{champion:161}} ult by slowing her, but youre completely fucking over anyone with low mobility and force them to take the entire remaining ult damage when they get hit by a single tick. 

the same champions who are already easier to hit in the first place get hit even harder.

if you wanted to give velkoz a tool to deal with mobility, then add a goddamn grounded debuff instead of a slow. otherwise youre only accomplishing the opposite.
